channel.title: Metals Industry News Feed
channel.description: Automated news feed for aluminum, steel, copper, and nickel industries

item.title: Indonesia Cuts Weda Bay Nickel Mining Quota, Prices Rise
item.description: Indonesia sharply cut PT Weda Bay Nickel's 2026 mining quota to 12 million wet metric tons from 32 million wet tons in 2025, causing nickel prices to climb. The LME benchmark three-month nickel contract rose 0.70% to $17,990 a ton, with the Shanghai Futures Exchange contract climbing 2.49% to 140,570 yuan per metric ton.

item.title: Weda Bay Nickel Receives Sharply Reduced 2026 Quota
item.description: Indonesia revised its total nickel ore production target to 260-270 million tons for 2026, down from 379 million tons in 2025, with the objective to support LME nickel prices within a stable $19,000-20,000/ton range. Project Blue forecasts a nickel market surplus of 249kt Ni in 2026, though higher prices may face resistance from downstream consumers due to structural shifts in EV battery markets and weak stainless steel demand.

item.title: Crude Oil Rises, Nickel Prices Extend Gains for Fourth Day, Silver Surges
item.description: Nickel prices rose for a fourth consecutive day, hitting a two-week high after Indonesia signaled significant production cuts. LME nickel futures climbed 2.23% to $17,880.0 per ton as market sentiment strengthened on expectations of constrained Indonesian supply.

item.title: SMM Nickel Midday Review: Nickel Prices Continue to Rise on February 12
item.description: SMM #1 refined nickel prices were quoted at 140,200-150,500 yuan/mt with an average price of 145,350 yuan/mt, up 2,750 yuan/mt on the day. Prices continued their upward momentum following Indonesia's production quota announcements.

item.title: Indonesia Nickel Mining Quota Cut Impacts Market
item.description: Following Indonesia's sharp cut to PT Weda Bay Nickel's mining quota, nickel prices climbed with the Shanghai Futures Exchange contract rising 2.49% to 140,570 yuan per metric ton and the London Metal Exchange benchmark rising 0.70% to $17,990 per ton. Analysts note that while prices are supported in the short term, Indonesia historically prevents prices from rising sustainably above $18,000 per tonne to protect domestic EV sector competitiveness.

item.title: Aluminum - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News

It hit a 4-week low of 3031 USD/T on February 9. Earlier in February, prices fell from a three-year high amid base metals pullback.

item.description: Macro sentiment lacks improvement, keeping aluminum prices subdued in the latest SMM weekly review. Broader market pressures continue to weigh on the metal.

item.title: What happened to gold, silver, platinum and copper today? Why are precious metal prices crashing sharply today? Gold, silver, platinum and copper price plunge: Is this the end of the bull run for metals?
item.description: Copper prices slid 2.78% to $5.80 per pound on February 12, 2026, amid a broader plunge in precious and industrial metals. The drop reflects technical pressure, macro uncertainty including slowing Chinese manufacturing signals, stronger US data, and anticipation of tighter financial conditions. Traders note this as a potential delayed reaction to strong nonfarm payrolls, with tomorrow's CPI report as the next volatility catalyst.

item.title: Henkel showcases new material innovations, sustainability concept and partner ecosystem at LOPEC 2026
item.description: Henkel introduces silver-plated copper (SPC) ink technology at LOPEC 2026 to counter high silver prices, offering cost efficiency and performance for printed electronics while emphasizing sustainability through recycled silver materials. The innovations include high-conductivity inks, self-regulating PTC inks for thermal management in batteries and wearables, and solutions for connectivity, mobility, and healthcare applications.

item.title: SMM Nickel Midday Review - Nickel Prices Continue to Rise on February 12
item.description: Nickel prices continued their upward trend on February 12, supported by strong January US Non-Farm Payrolls data that exceeded expectations. The positive labor market data influenced commodity markets and contributed to nickel price gains.

item.title: Vale posts $3.8 billion Q4 loss on nickel assets impairment
item.description: Brazilian mining company Vale reported a $3.8 billion net loss in Q4 2025, primarily due to a $3.5 billion impairment on nickel assets in Canada triggered by downward revisions in long-term nickel price assumptions. The loss reflects broader market challenges in the nickel sector.

item.title: HRC Steel Hits 23-month High
item.description: HRC Steel increased to 970.00 USD/T, the highest since January 2024. Over the past 4 weeks, Hot-Rolled Coil Steel gained 3.3%, and in the last 12 months, it increased 31.83%.

item.title: What happened to gold, silver, platinum and copper today? Why are precious metal prices crashing sharply today?
item.description: Copper slid 2.78% to $5.80 per pound on February 12, 2026, amid a broader plunge in metal prices including gold, silver, and platinum. The drop reflects technical pressure, macro uncertainty, slowing Chinese manufacturing signals, and reactions to strong US data. Traders eye upcoming CPI data for potential volatility.

item.title: The Nickel Report
item.description: The report covers regulatory updates from PHMSA regarding hazardous materials shipping standards, including new regulations for sodium ion batteries aligned with lithium ion battery standards. It also discusses companies reconsidering sustainability targets due to economic pressures and challenges in meeting interim decarbonization goals.

item.title: STEEL METAL RATE, NEWS & TREND - 12 FEB 2026
item.description: Indian steel markets saw declines: MS ingot at 44,900, old scrap at 33,000, alloy scrap down 300 to 33,200; TMT prices fell 300/ton in Raipur, 500/ton in Mumbai. Ingot support at 44,700, resistance at 45,100. Global updates include 62% Fe fines CFR Qingdao below $102/ton, Tangshan billet stable at $420/ton on Feb 11, and Shagang holding rebar prices steady at $499/ton.

item.title: Aluminium Prices Soar as Tariffs and Energy Costs Reshape the Market
item.description: Aluminium prices reached nearly four-year highs on LME, with U.S. premiums hitting a record above $1/pound due to high energy costs, capacity closures, trade disputes, and rising demand. Goldman Sachs raised its H1 2026 forecast to $3,150/ton from $2,575/ton. This benefits producers like Alcoa and Century Aluminum but pressures downstream sectors.

item.title: Why are aluminium, copper, nickel and tin prices going down today and will base metals continue to fall or rise again?
item.description: Base metals prices on LME fell despite early aluminum strength, with aluminum down 0.1% to $3,100/ton by late trading due to position squaring, weaker sentiment, U.S. data, and pre-Lunar New Year China demand slowdown. Other metals like nickel, zinc, lead, and tin also declined. Future direction hinges on post-holiday China demand and tight supply.

item.title: Trump plans to roll back tariffs on metal and aluminium goods, FT reports
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump is planning to scale back tariffs on steel and aluminium goods, per Financial Times and Reuters. This development occurs amid recent aluminum price volatility.

item.title: Century Aluminum Backs New U.S. Smelter Built Around Next-Generation Smelting Technology
item.description: Century Aluminum Company and Emirates Global Aluminum (EGA) are partnering to build an advanced primary aluminum smelter in Inola, Oklahoma, using next-generation EX smelting technology. The facility is expected to produce up to 750,000 metric tons of aluminum annually, more than doubling current U.S. capacity, while reducing energy consumption and emissions. Construction is expected to begin as early as 2026, with commercial production anticipated before the end of the decade.

item.title: Metals Innovation Initiative Appoints Sustainability Project Coordinator
item.description: The Metals Innovation Initiative (MI2) has appointed Laura Haury as sustainability project coordinator to focus on aluminum recycling efforts, environmental education, and outreach programs. Haury brings decades of environmental engineering and manufacturing sustainability experience, and will work to increase aluminum recycling rates across Kentucky and beyond through partnerships with The Recycling Society.

item.title: Decarbonisation and Raw Material Independence at Stake
item.description: Speira, a European aluminum recycler, urges EU action to boost competitiveness and protect aluminum recycling, noting that recycling processes can avoid up to 95 percent of CO2 emissions compared to primary production. The company has joined the Antwerp Declaration to advocate for sustainable steps toward European competitiveness and future-proof planning security in the circular economy.

item.title: HRC Steel Price Update
item.description: HRC steel fell to $980.05/ton on February 13, 2026, down 0.10% from the previous day, though prices have risen 4.37% over the past month and are up 27.58% compared to the same time last year. The commodity has shown volatility, reaching a 36-week high of $941/ton on January 28, 2026.

item.title: A new way to make steel could reduce America's reliance on imports
item.description: Hertha Metals is advancing a novel single-step steelmaking process using natural gas and electricity on molten iron oxide, operating a 1-tonne-per-day pilot plant near Houston since late 2024. The company plans to build a 10,000-ton-per-year plant this year, reaching full capacity by end-2027, also producing high-purity iron for magnets to onshore critical materials. This innovation aims to outcompete traditional methods and integrate with existing U.S. steel infrastructure.

item.title: A new way to make steel could reduce America's reliance on imports
item.description: Hertha Metals has developed a new steel production system using natural gas and electricity that reduces iron ore to molten steel in a single step, eliminating the need for coking and sintering plants. The process uses 30 percent less energy and is 25 percent more cost-competitive than conventional American steel mills while reducing emissions. The company is scaling from its current 1-tonne-per-day pilot plant to a 10,000-ton-per-year facility expected to reach full capacity by end of 2027.

item.title: Border States Commodity Update: February 2026
item.description: Major copper miners reported strong 2025 fourth-quarter production results. Rio Tinto achieved an 11% increase in copper production, exceeding 800,000 metric tons, driven by the Oyu Tolgoi mine in Mongolia with a 5% year-over-year rise in Q4 output. Freeport-McMoRan posted better-than-expected results despite a production decline at Indonesia’s Grasberg mine due to a natural disaster, expecting 85% recovery by mid-2026.

item.title: Rio Tinto Wants to Further U.S. Copper Investment Amid Tariffs
item.description: Rio Tinto is advancing the Resolution copper mine project in the U.S., potentially producing up to 500,000 tons of copper concentrate annually from 43.2 million tons of ore over 40 years, with permitting estimated for completion by February 13, 2026. The company is also investing in Bingham Canyon mine expansions, including a $1.5 billion Phase II project to extend life to 2032 and add 1 million tons of refined copper, plus a $500 million North Rim Skarn development for additional capacity by end-2026.

item.title: SMM Nickel Sulphate Daily Review - February 13: Trading Sluggish Before the Holiday
item.description: Battery-grade nickel sulphate prices remained stable at 31,635 yuan/mt on February 13, with trading activity slowing ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday. Market activity is expected to remain subdued during the holiday period.

item.title: Vale reports $3.8 billion loss in Q4 due to nickel asset impairment
item.description: Mining giant Vale reported a $3.8 billion fourth-quarter loss, primarily driven by a $3.5 billion impairment on its nickel assets in Canada due to expectations of lower nickel prices. The impairment reflects broader concerns about the nickel market outlook.

item.title: Vale posts $3.8bn loss on nickel impairment; analysts welcome core profit
item.description: Vale recorded a $3.5 billion impairment on nickel assets in its Base Metals division, contributing to a $3.8 billion quarterly loss that significantly exceeded analyst expectations of a $2.7 billion profit. The impairment reflects declining nickel price forecasts.

item.title: World's biggest nickel mine in Indonesia told to cut output
item.description: PT Weda Bay Nickel, the world's largest nickel mine, has been ordered to reduce its 2026 production quota to 12 million tonnes of ore, down from 42 million tonnes in 2025—a 71% reduction. This cut is part of Indonesia's broader strategy to restrict nickel supply, as the country produces approximately 65% of global nickel.

item.title: Indonesia's Weda Bay Nickel facing quota cut by 70%, causing nickel prices to surge
item.description: The Indonesian government has drastically cut the production quota for PT Weda Bay Nickel to 12 million tonnes, triggering significant price movements in global nickel markets. The reduction reflects Indonesia's effort to tighten supply and support prices.

item.title: Indonesia risks oversupply in Class 2 nickel: Expert
item.description: An expert analysis suggests that Indonesia's plan to sharply reduce its nickel ore production quota may paradoxically create oversupply risks in Class 2 nickel markets. The article discusses potential market implications of the production cuts.

item.title: Trump signals rollback on 50% steel and aluminum tariffs – what it means for solar
item.description: The Trump administration is preparing to scale back up to 50% tariffs on imported steel and aluminum to address an affordability crisis. This could significantly lower costs for the US solar industry, where aluminum frames now represent 14% of solar panel manufacturing costs. The rollback may ease Balance of System costs for utility-scale and residential solar projects.

item.description: The Trump administration is reportedly preparing to scale back up to 50% tariffs on imported steel and aluminum to address affordability concerns. item.title: Tariffs: The Pedal Keeps Hitting the Metal | February 2026
item.description: Since Trump's 50% tariff on aluminum in June, Midwest premiums and prices have risen monthly, with premiums from $0.40s to $1.04 and LME up $600 per tonne. A potential 25% tariff on imports from partners like Canada could add $0.35-0.37 per lb to US premiums. 2026 LME aluminum forecasts average around $3,250 per forecasts from analysts.

item.description: Taylor's Scrapyard reports continued steel price rises in early 2026, building on January gains into February, following seasonal trends of strengthening demand from mills and manufacturing. This upward momentum creates opportunities for scrap metal sellers as consumption increases in construction and industrial sectors. The company offers metal recycling and demolition services in Georgia.

item.title: Trump plans to ease some steel, aluminum tariffs
item.description: Donald Trump plans to scale back select steel and aluminum tariffs amid price concerns. The announcement caused shares of major producers like Alcoa and Century Aluminum to decline significantly, while benchmark aluminum prices on the LME fell to one-week lows.

item.title: Ryerson and Olympic Steel Announce Successful Closing of Merger
item.description: Ryerson and Olympic Steel have completed their merger, forming the second-largest North American metals service center with expected $120 million in annual synergies by early 2028 through procurement, efficiency, and optimization. The combined entity enhances processing capabilities, geographic expansion, and asset utilization to improve service amid a manufacturing demand upcycle.

item.title: Steel and aluminum tariffs, Trump reconsiders: Prysmian sinks, Tenaris rises on the Milan Stock Exchange
item.description: Tenaris's stock rose on the Milan Stock Exchange following reports that Trump may reconsider steel and aluminum tariffs. The company continues strategic operations, including a contract worth up to €550 million with Enedis to supply electrical structures for modernizing France's electrical grid over seven years with options for three additional years.

item.title: Prysmian Agrees Framework Agreement With Enedis To Modernise The French Power Grid
item.description: Prysmian signed a €550 million contract with Enedis to supply the full range of medium-voltage cables over seven years (2026-2032). The agreement includes the use of recycled materials such as over 12% recycled aluminum and over 30% recycled copper, aligning with both companies' sustainability and circular economy goals.

item.title: Prysmian Signs EUR500 Million Deal for French Power Grid
item.description: Prysmian announced a seven-year agreement with Enedis valued at €500 million to become the sole supplier for medium-voltage cables. The partnership aims to enhance circular economy practices and reduce carbon emissions through the use of renewable energy sources and recycled materials in cable production.

item.title: Aluminum Falls on Likely US Tariff Slash
item.description: Aluminum futures in the UK fell to $3,050 per tonne, continuing the pullback from a three-year high. The decline follows reports of a likely US tariff reduction on aluminum imports.

item.description: Aluminum prices remained strong on February 14 despite weak downstream orders. Aluminum billet processing fees in three regions stayed flat compared to the previous day.

item.title: Aluminum price rises as looming smelter closure adds to supply strains
item.description: South32 Ltd. is proceeding with plans to mothball its Mozal smelter in Mozambique next month, a major supplier to the European market. The closure adds to growing supply constraints as Chinese smelters near government-imposed production capacity caps and 50% US tariffs have caused imports to slump, with aluminum prices rallying 17% last year and 5.5% so far in 2026.

item.title: Bessent discusses possible narrowing of steel, aluminum tariffs
item.description: Treasury Secretary Bessent commented on reports of potential tariff rollbacks, stating that any changes would likely involve clarification on incidental objects rather than broad scaling back. The Trump administration has imposed 50% tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, with discussions ongoing about possible modifications.

item.title: Bessent discusses possible narrowing of steel, aluminum tariffs
item.description: U.S. Treasury Secretary Bessent discussed the Trump administration's potential plan to scale back 50 percent tariffs on steel and aluminum imports to address rising affordability issues. Officials believe the tariffs are hurting consumers by raising prices for goods including pie tins and food-and-drink cans.

item.title: Trump plans to roll back some tariffs on steel, aluminium goods
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump plans to scale back some tariffs on steel and aluminum goods, according to Financial Times reporting. The move comes as Commerce Department and trade officials believe the tariffs are hurting consumers, with shares of major steelmakers declining following the announcement.

item.title: Bessent discusses possible narrowing of steel, aluminum tariffs
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Bessent discussed potential narrowing of 50% tariffs on steel and aluminum imports and derivatives like appliances in a CNBC interview. The Trump administration imposed these tariffs, but changes may clarify incidental items ahead of midterm elections. He noted it would be the president's decision after consulting the US Trade Rep.

item.title: Nickel Futures Prices Inched Lower in February
item.description: Nickel prices declined in February amid macroeconomic headwinds including higher-than-expected CPI (6.4%) and PPI (6%) data, along with hawkish Federal Reserve commentary raising interest rate concerns. The LME announced on February 23 that Asian nickel trading would resume on March 20, which also contributed to price declines.

item.title: Philippine nickel sales to Indonesia to jump after Jakarta curbs
item.description: Philippine nickel ore shipments to Indonesia could double to 30 million tons in 2026 following Indonesia's production cuts. Philippine miners see this as an opportunity to fill the supply gap created by Indonesia's domestic output reduction, though expansion may be limited by aging mines and slow approval processes.

item.title: Aluminum pulls back after a one-week low following market digests reporting Trump may ease tariffs
item.description: Aluminum prices fell to their lowest level in a week on Friday after reports that the U.S. may slash some import tariffs. The benchmark three-month aluminum on the LME lost as much as 2.7% but reduced losses to 0.9% by end of trading at $3,074/t.

item.title: Aluminum pulls back after a one-week low following market digests reporting Trump may ease tariffs
item.description: Aluminum prices fell to a one-week low on Friday, dropping as much as 2.7% to $3,074 per metric ton on the LME after reports of potential U.S. tariff reductions. The metal had peaked due to supply concerns but pulled back amid tariff speculation. Alcoa and Century Aluminum shares declined alongside steelmakers.

item.title: EU steelmakers demand electricity price cut to safeguard the bloc's competitiveness
item.description: European steelmakers are urging the EU to reduce electricity prices to around €50/MWh to protect the bloc's steel industry competitiveness. The demand addresses high energy costs impacting production viability amid global challenges.

item.title: Nornickel, a Russian nickel producer, will shift some of its nickel production to a copper plant for repairs
item.description: Nornickel plans to maintain 2026 nickel production at 193,000-203,000 metric tonnes by shifting some output to a copper facility during a 270-day smelting furnace upgrade at Nadezhda Metallurgical Plant in 2027. This unconventional approach offsets half the plant's capacity loss. The company is preparing production lines for pilot tests this year.

item.title: Trump to Roll Back Some Tariffs on Steel, Aluminum
item.description: Aluminum prices sank to a one-week low after reports that Trump may trim import tariffs, with LME's three-month contract slipping over 1.18% to $3,063.50 a ton and Shanghai's most-active contract falling 1.76% to 23,195 yuan a ton. Trading slowed in China ahead of the Lunar New Year break from February 15 to 24. Copper prices also tumbled amid these pressures.

item.title: Trump Moves to Roll Back Metal & Aluminum Tariffs as Affordability Pressures Mount
item.description: The Trump administration plans targeted easing of metal tariffs ahead of 2026 midterms to address affordability for voters and manufacturers. This follows earlier bolstering from Iran tensions but recent drops on deal prospects, weakening demand, and supply growth per IEA forecasts. Prices show slowing downside amid persistent oversupply concerns.

item.title: Mid-February 2026 Steel Pipe Market: Navigating the Final Stretch of the Holiday Hiatus
item.description: Steel pipe production remains idle but is expected to resume in a staggered manner from the week of February 23rd onwards, with full stable output anticipated by early March. The supply chain is preparing for reactivation, with initial post-holiday lead times potentially extending to 50-65 days as manufacturers clear significant order backlogs from before the holiday shutdown.

item.title: Copper Cables: Antitrust Launches Investigation into Alleged Cartel
item.description: Italy's Antitrust Authority has initiated an investigation into major low-voltage copper cable manufacturers, including Prysmian Cavi e Sistemi Italia Srl, for alleged price-fixing since 2005. Inspections were conducted yesterday at company offices, distributors, and the National Federation of Electrical Material Wholesalers, supported by Guardia di Finanza. Prysmian shares dropped 1.26% in response, though analysts view the impact as negligible given the small market share.

item.title: Steel industry faces challenges amid domestic focus shift
item.description: Vietnamese steel companies are shifting focus to the domestic market due to weakening export demand and trade barriers, leading to intense competition and compressed profit margins. Companies like Nam Kim Steel are expanding production capacity with new plants such as the Phú Mỹ Steel plant set to start in Q1 2026, but simultaneous expansions by competitors like VNSteel and Dong A Steel risk oversupply. Analysts highlight challenges in achieving supply-demand balance and rising operating costs impacting profitability.

item.description: International Wire reports the copper base price at $8.4000 effective February 16, 2026, for Omega - Camden. Additional indices include COMEX copper monthly average at $5.88100 and LME copper cash settlement at $5.9370 for January 2026. This provides a current pricing snapshot amid ongoing market trends.

item.title: Global copper exchange stocks top 1Mt for first time in two decades
item.description: Copper stocks on the world's three biggest metal exchanges exceeded one-million metric tons for the first time in more than two decades. This buildup signals shifting market dynamics potentially impacting prices and supply trends.

item.title: Global copper exchange stocks top 1Mt for first time in two decades
item.description: Copper stocks on the world's three biggest metal exchanges have exceeded one-million metric tons for the first time in more than two decades. This buildup indicates shifting supply dynamics amid recent market pressures. The increase highlights potential easing of immediate tightness despite ongoing production challenges.

item.title: The Monday Report - 16 February 2026
item.description: Spot nickel prices fell 5.10% to $7.63/lb in the latest futures update. The report covers broader metals market movements, including gains in gold and silver amid expectations for UK CPI data. Energy futures show minor declines in crude oil prices.

item.title: Copper Values Retreat to $5.9 Per Pound as Chinese Industrial Engine Idles for Lunar New Year
item.description: Copper futures settled near $5.90 per pound due to a seasonal slowdown in China during Lunar New Year starting February 17, 2026, leading to reduced industrial activity and inventory buildup. This follows volatility with peaks near $6.50 in late January. Post-holiday recovery in March could see range-bound trading between $5.75 and $6.10, with potential rallies if stimulus boosts demand.

item.title: BHP Earnings Feb. 17: 62C Dividend Seen, Copper Guide Raised
item.description: BHP has lifted its FY26 copper production guidance to 1,900–2,000 kt ahead of its half-year results on February 17, 2026. The company highlights strong copper performance and resilience in China's commodity demand. This guidance uplift supports valuation and dividend confidence amid favorable prices.

item.title: Norilsk Nickel will be the first in the world to launch a unique tunneling complex in the Arctic
item.description: Norilsk Nickel plans to test its unique 700-ton Norda mechanized tunneling complex at the Taimyrsky mine in Q2 2026, targeting 150,000 tons of ore production that year from the Severnaya-4 deposit. The equipment promises record penetration speeds and improved safety. All specialists are trained, and assembly is underway.

item.title: U.S., Nippon Steel to reline Gary Works blast furnace this year
item.description: U.S. Steel and Nippon Steel plan to reline blast furnace #14 at Gary Works starting May 2026, costing $350 million and lasting 100 days until August, ensuring no supply interruptions. The company will invest $900 million in 2026, followed by $800 million in 2027 and $1.1 billion in 2028. Local activists oppose the project over environmental concerns, advocating for greener steelmaking.

item.title: U.S., Nippon Steel to reline Gary Works blast furnace this year
item.description: U.S. Steel and Nippon Steel plan to reline blast furnace #14 at the Gary Works facility later this year as part of a $900 million investment in 2026, followed by further investments in 2027 and 2028. The project aims to implement high-productivity, energy-efficient technologies to reduce CO2 emissions intensity. This follows board approval in December 2025 for the $350 million reline of the facility's largest blast furnace.

item.title: BHP Boosts Profit Amid Copper Surge
item.description: BHP reported a 28% profit surge to US$5.64 billion in the first half, driven by increased copper earnings and strong margins, allowing it to raise full-year 2026 copper production guidance to 1.9-2 million tonnes. Output from the Escondida mine and other Chilean operations contributed to this revision. The company declared an interim dividend of US73¢ per share, up from the previous year.

item.title: Copper becomes BHP's biggest earnings driver
item.description: BHP has increased its group copper production guidance for the 2026 financial year to between 1.9-million and 2.0-million tonnes. Copper has become the company's largest earnings driver.

item.title: Copper Becomes BHP's Top Earnings Driver in 2026
item.description: Copper has become BHP's largest earnings driver by 2026, boosting earnings with high margins.

item.title: What's Behind the Copper Hype? A Fireside Conversation with BHP Americas President Brandon Craig
item.description: CSIS hosts a discussion on copper market trends, including tightening supply, declining ore grades, and geopolitical risks affecting energy, data centers, and defense technologies. BHP Americas President Brandon Craig joins to explore U.S. strategies for copper security, investment, and innovation in the value chain. The event underscores copper's role in technological leadership and economic resilience.

item.title: Nickel price jumps as Indonesia’s top mine cuts output
item.description: LME nickel prices rose 2% to $17,835/tonne after Indonesia slashed PT Weda Bay Nickel's 2026 ore quota to 12 million tonnes from 42 million in 2025, extending a 20% rally. Total national quotas are set at 260-270 million tonnes, down from 379 million in 2025, tightening global supply. Eramet plans to request a quota revision.

item.title: Acciaierie d'Italia to start preferential negotiations with Azerbaijani consortium on acquisition of former Ilva plants
item.description: Extraordinary commissioners of Acciaierie d’Italia and ILVA in extraordinary administration have requested authorization from Italy’s Ministry of Enterprises and Made in Italy to begin preferential negotiations with an Azerbaijani consortium (Baku Steel Company CJSC and Azerbaijan Investment Company OJSC) for the sale of the former Ilva steel plants.[8] Ten proposals had been received by the January 10 deadline, and the chosen consortium was selected based on criteria including financial stability, industrial sustainability, and expected benefits for employment and local communities.[8]
